text: welcome to the global Round Table this
series focuses on the future of economic
competition I'm paraga joined by a very
distinguished panel including deisa moo
Daniel Alman and Anan gardas today's
topic is actually the power of language
we can't be complacent anymore in the
west about controlling the financial
levers of the economy but what about
controlling the language of the global
economy which is of course English
what's the future of that Advantage for
the West it's interesting English is no
longer an instrument of soft power in
the way uh that I think a lot of
Americans assume it is it's purely an
instrument it is an instrument for the
people who learn it to get ahead and I
think we still have a residual Cold War
idea that every time someone learns
English they like us more they like
democracy more they like our policies
there's a whole number of people in the
world today who are learning English as
a tool for getting their next promotion
who still need to be convinced about our
values and ideas doesn't it still matter
to be better at English I think there's
an economic Advantage but it's not
necessarily in the quality think about
education in general when babies are
born they're born with as much education
today as they were born with a 100 years
ago or a thousand years ago and yet you
need so much more education to get ahead
in the global economy today not having
to spend extra time learning English is
an advantage that American babies have
it may not be a big Advantage but maybe
it's a couple years that they can study
something else if only we would devote
more time to something else I think
that's exactly right because they aren't
unfortunately there isn't this crowding
out tradeoff it's not the fact that
Americans are not spending time learning
English doesn't mean they're not
spending time doing maths and Science
and if you look at the international
organization the oecd's Pisa survey
every year the fact of the matter is
that Americans are underperforming in
mathematics in Sciences but also in
reading so I mean you have to then ask
yourself what exactly is going on even
Chinese are learning English in record
numbers before during and now after the
Olympic Games which they played host to
could it really be that countries that
are not even native English speaking uh
such as China and others will actually
disintermediate the Western sort of grip
on English in terms of jobs to disagree
with Dan a bit if you think about the us
or England uh the UK a certain number of
people within those countries speaks a
kind of English that is globally
competitive in the kind of language of
global business but most Americans uh
and most people in Britain don't speak
an English that gets them a job at City
Bank tomorrow anyway so I think we can
overblow the number of people who speak
the kind of English we're talking about
as the language of global business uh
even within english- speaking countries
I think if you make that distinction
though you start to bring in other
cultural factors there may not be people
in India or China which we are viewing
as these big threats to American
dominants who are learning the right
mindset to work at City Bank so you know
we might as well throw these other
factors into thex as well even across
African countries people are learning
Chinese um and I think there's something
to be said there because governments in
Africa places like Cameroon are actually
devoting scare relatively scarce
resources to learning Chinese um over uh
over English so we have to ask what this
trend really means but I have to ask
whether a world where English and
Chinese are the global languages is not
a world that's worse off where there's
one Global language one standard that
everybody can use isn't that an economic
efficiency by itself but I don't think
we'll ever be able to force a
standardization so we have to come to
grips with the fact that there are now
multiple Global languages English and
Chinese and potentially others and
beyond that English itself isn't the
only language because as you said
earlier we have to also know math and
science and those are in a way more
Universal than English itself but
certainly language and how we Define it
and use it is going to be integral to
the future of competition in the global
economy thanks very much for your
insights more on that and other relevant
topics at bigthink.com
